page.title: direction of net force on person in roller coaster
page.contents: You are riding a roller coaster which has a loop. At the instant that you pass through the top of the loop you are at a minimum speed, so you are neither speeding up nor slowing down.  So we can treat this moment as uniform circular motion.  Which way is the vector sum of forces on you at this moment?

answer.response: Yes, since down is towards the centre of the circle you are moving in.
No. This is uniform circular motion (just like the car at the bottom of the valley in the lecture). At the top of the loop the centre of the circle is below you. So the vector sum of forces is down.

answer.answer_text: forward (i.e. in the direction of your motion)
answer.response: No, you may have a persistent confusion between velocity and acceleration. We have seen (draw the motion diagram) that in uniform circular motion the acceleration points toward the centre of the circle. Newton's 2nd Law tells us that the net force acts in the same direction as the acceleration. So the vector sum of forces acts down since that is the direction to the centre of the circle.

No. Are you thinking that the speed is constant so the acceleration should be zero? Acceleration is rate of change of velocity, and the direction of the velocity is changing. So the acceleration is not zero and neither is the vector sum of forces.

page.title: Vertical circle
page.contents: Think about the part of the video where I was swinging the ball around on the string.  Suppose I swing it in a vertical circle in front of me instead of a horizontal circle above my head.  As the ball passes through the bottom of the circle it is at its maximum speed and so it is neither speeding up nor slowing down.  Thus, we can treat that moment as uniform circular motion.  Which way is the vector sum of forces on it at this instant?

answer.response: Yes, up is the direction to the centre of the circle, so that is the direction of the net force.
No. At the instant the ball is passing through the bottom of the circle the direction to the centre of the circle is up. So the vector sum of forces would point up.

answer.answer_text: Right, just as it was in the lecture.
answer.response: No, at the instant the ball is passing through the bottom of the circle the direction to the centre of the circle is up. So the vector sum of forces would point up.

You may have a persistent misunderstanding leading you to think that the vector sum of forces is always in the direction of motion. Remember that the Law of Inertia tells us that no force is needed to keep an object in motion. A motion diagram would show you that the acceleration at this moment is up, and so the vector sum of forces must also be up.

answer.answer_text: Since the speed isn't changing the acceleration is zero and so is the vector sum of forces.
answer.response: Acceleration is not rate of change of speed. It is rate of change of velocity. A motion diagram would show you that the acceleration at this moment is up, and so the vector sum of forces must also be up.

page.title: ants on turntable (speed)
page.contents: Two ants are standing still on a turntable (in case you don't know, a turntable is an ancient device used to play "records" which were an audio recording format used in antiquity). The turntable is turning. Ant A is 1.0 cm from the center of the turntable. Ant B is 5.0 cm from the center of the turntable. Which ant has the greater speed?

answer.response: Yes. Both ants complete a "trip around the circle" in the same amount of time. Ant B travels further in that time so it is going faster.

No. Both ants complete a "trip around the circle" in the same amount of time (the same amount of time it takes for the turntable to go around once). Ant B travels further in that time because it is going around a larger circle, so it is going faster.

answer.answer_text: The ants are moving at the same speed.
answer.response: No. Both ants complete a "trip around the circle" in the same amount of time (the same amount of time it takes for the turntable to go around once). So their *periods* are the same and their angular speeds are the same. But the question asked about speed, not period or angular speed. Ant B travels further in that time because it is going around a larger circle, so it is going faster.

Relative to the turntable they are stationary. But if you were on a merry go round which was turning I doubt you would describe yourself as stationary. We are talking about the ants' speeds relative to the ground, which is certainly not zero.

We do have enough information to conclude which ant travels further. Both ants complete a "trip around the circle" in the same amount of time (the same amount of time it takes for the turntable to go around once). Ant B travels further in that time because it is going around a larger circle, so it is going faster. We can't *calculate* their speeds with the information given but we certainly know which is going faster.

page.title: Signs of angular velocity and angular acceleration
page.contents: A piece of gum is stuck to a disk.  The disk is rotating clockwise as shown.  The disk is slowing down.  What are the signs of the angular velocity and angular acceleration of the gum?

answer.response: Yes.

Did you think that the angular acceleration is negative because the disk is slowing down? Just like with acceleration components earlier in the course, the sign of the angular acceleration does not tell you whether the object is speeding up or slowing down. Think of what the angular velocity vs. time graph must look like and decide whether it has a positive or negative slope.

No. Counterclockwise is positive and the disk is rotating clockwise. Also, did you think that angular acceleration is negative because the disk is slowing down? That's not what the sign of angular acceleration tells you.
No. Counterclockwise is positive and the disk is rotating clockwise.

page.title: Angle in radians
page.contents: A person is walking around a circular track.  The track has a radius of 20 m.  The person has walked 80 m.  What angle have they walked through?

answer.response: Yes.

No. Part of the point of using radians is that in most situations we don't have annoying factors of pi floating around because of it. A radius is 20 m. The person has walked 80 m, which is the equivalent of 4 radii. So they have walked through an angle of 4 rad.
No. You seem to have just replaced meters with radians.
No. A radius is 20 m. The person has gone 80 m, which is the equivalent of 4 radii. So they have walked through an angle of 4 rad.

page.title: Angular speed
page.contents: An object is going around a circle with a radius of 5 m.  The object is moving at a speed of 15 m/s.  What is its angular speed?

answer.response: Yes.

No. Part of the point of using radians is that in most situations we don't have annoying factors of pi floating around because of it. A radius is 5 m. Every second this object goes 15 m, which is the equivalent of 3 radii. So the angular speed is 3 rad/s.
No. You seem to have just replaced meters with radians.
No. A radius is 5 m. Every second this object goes 15 m, which is the equivalent of 3 radii. So the angular speed is 3 rad/s.

page.title: period vs. speed
page.contents: Amy runs around a circular track with a period of 120 s. Meanwhile Brian runs around the same track with a period of 150 s. Which runner is running faster?

answer.response: Yes.

Please use common sense. In a race the person who completes the race in less time must have run faster. Amy took less time to go around the circle so she must have been running faster. They have gone the same distance. Amy did it in less time. By the definition of speed she must have gone faster.

answer.answer_text: We need to know the track’s radius to be able to answer this.
answer.response: Please use common sense. In a race the person who completes the race in less time must have run faster. Amy took less time to go around the circle so she must have been running faster. We don't need to know the radius of the track to conclude who was running faster.

answer.answer_text: We can't determine this from their periods.
answer.response: Please use common sense. In a race the person who completes the race in less time must have run faster. Amy took less time to go around the circle so she must have been running faster. If all we want to know is who ran faster then their periods are enough to determine this.

answer.response: Yes. The acceleration is inward and the velocity is tangent to the circle,.
